awd_abstract_narration:
The main purpose of this project is to investigate the connection between two different areas of mathematics: representation theory of combinatorial categories and commutative algebra. This is a worthwhile goal, since it allows one to apply tools and perspectives from one area to the other, which can lead to new insights. This strategy has been applied successfully a number of times, leading to new results in a diverse range of areas, including chemistry, statistics, and geometry. The project also has a strong focus on education. The PI will work with undergraduate students, and he will organize a conference on this topic that will introduce graduate students to this relatively new field of mathematics. The PI will also make various mathematical materials (such as filmed lectures) available freely on the internet.

There are two main classes of problems within the project. The first is to determine the extent to which ideas from commutative algebra can be applied to representations of combinatorial categories in general. For instance, the PI and a collaborator carried over the theory of Grobner bases to the categorical side. This led to many interesting results (such as the resolution of the Lannes--Schwartz Artinian conjecture), but raised a large number of questions as well. The second class of problems is to develop more deeply the representation theory of particular combinatorial categories of interest. Some of the main examples are twisted commutative algebras, where the connection to commutative algebra is particularly strong.

por.por_cntn:
In science and mathematics, one often encounters systems with a large number of variables. In many cases, the variables in such a system appear in a symmetrical manner. For example, in statistical mechanics one might model a cloud of gas by using one variable for each molecule, resulting in a system with trillions upon trillions of variables; since each molecule is subject to the same physical laws, the variables will play symmetrical roles in the model. In the last fifteen years, mathematicians have discovered many new properties of symmetrical systems of large numbers of variables. These discoveries belong to the a new field called representation stability.

The primary research goal of this project was to further develop the mathematical theory of representation stability. The project successfully achieved this goal: it produced more than 45 original research papers. These papers contain an abundance of new results related to representation stability, and have greatly advanced the state of the art. Preprints of all papers are freely available to the public on the arXiv.

This project also had educational aspects. The "Michigan Representation Stability Week" was held in August 2018. This week consisted of a three-day workshop to introduce students to representation stability, followed by a two-day conference in which original research in the area was presented. The week was attended by more than 35 students and 15 experts.

Additionally, this project afforded direct research opportunities to nine undergraduate students, five graduate students, and six post-docs.
